Make Me Puke] ''Sequential Tart'' February 2008 and failing to address gay issues.Vincent, Keith (2007) "[http://www.upress.umn.edu/Books/L/lunning_mechademia2.html A Japanese Electra and her Queer Progeny]" ''Mechademia 2'' pp.64–79{{cite web|url=http://moongsil.com/study/yaoi_eng.pdf |title=Reading Yaoi Comics: An Analysis of Korean Girls' Fandom |last=Noh |first=Sueen |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928081809/http://moongsil.com/study/yaoi_eng.pdf |archivedate=September 28, 2007 |df=mdy }} [[Homophobia]], when it is presented as an issue at all,Masaki, Lyle. (January 6, 2008) [http://www.afterelton.com/Print/2008/1/yaoi? “Yowie!”: The Stateside appeal of boy-meets-boy Yaoi comics] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517082410/http://www.afterelton.com/Print/2008/1/yaoi |date=May 17, 2008 }} ''[[AfterEllen.com and AfterElton.com|AfterElton.com]]'' is used as a plot device to "heighten the drama",Brenner, Robyn [http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6477427.html Romance by Any Other Name] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607130508/http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6477427.html |date=June 7, 2011 }} or to show the purity of the leads' love. Matt Thorn has suggested that as BL is a romance narrative, having strong political themes may be a "turn off" to the readers.[[Matt Thorn|Thorn, Matthew]]. (2004) [http://matt-thorn.com/shoujo_manga/outofhand/ “Girls And Women Getting Out Of Hand: The Pleasure And Politics Of Japan's Amateur Comics Community.”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161214162110/http://matt-thorn.com/shoujo_manga/outofhand/ |date=December 14, 2016 }} pp. 169–86, In ''Fanning the Flames: Fans and Consumer Culture in Contemporary Japan'', William W. Kelly, ed., [[State University of New York]] Press. {{ISBN|0-7914-6032-0}}. Retrieved August 12, 2008. Critics state that the genre challenges heteronormativity via the "queer" ''[[bishōnen]]''.{{cite journal|last1=Welker|first1=James|title=Beautiful, Borrowed, and Bent: 'Boys' Love' as Girls' Love in ''Shôjo Manga''|journal=Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society|date=2006|volume=31|issue=3|pages=841–870|doi=10.1086/498987}}{{cite journal|last1=Wood|first1= Andrea| date=Spring 2006 |title='Straight' Women, Queer Texts: Boy-Love Manga and the Rise of a Global Counterpublic|journal= ''[[WSQ: Women's Studies Quarterly]]''|volume=34|issue=1–2|pages= 394–414|jstor=40004766}} There is also a style of manga called [[Bara (genre)|Bara]], which is typically written by gay men for a gay male adult audience. Bara often has more realistic themes than yaoi and is more likely to acknowledge homophobia and the taboo nature of homosexuality in Japan. While western commentators sometimes group bara and yaoi together, writers and fans consider them separate genres.{{cite web|url=http://www.csuchico.edu/~mtoku/vc/Articles/toku/Wil_Toku_BoysLove.html|title="Boys' Love," Yaoi, and Art Education: Issues of Power and Pedagogy|publisher=}} ==Film and television== In general, speculative fiction on television and film has lagged behind literature in its portrayals of homosexuality.{{cite web |url=http://www.afterellen.com/TV/2007/10/topscifimoments |title=Top Lesbian SciFi Moments |accessdate=2008-11-25 |year=2007 |work=[[AfterEllen.com and AfterElton.com|AfterEllen.com]] |quote=Beginning in the '70s in books, the '80s in movies and the '90s on TV, lesbian and bisexual characters and delightfully queer moments have appeared with increasing frequency. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130116081755/http://www.afterellen.com/TV/2007/10/topscifimoments |archivedate=January 16, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} Sexual relationships in major speculative fiction franchises have generally been depicted as heterosexual in nature. Inter-species and inter-ethnic relationships have been commonly depicted, while homosexual relationships and transgender characters are more rare. ===Film=== LGBT characters in films began to appear more regularly only in the 1980s. Films in the late 1920s and early 1930s reflected the liberal attitudes of the day and could include [[sexual innuendo]]s and references to homosexuality,{{cite book | author=LaSalle, Mick | title=Dangerous Men: Pre-Code Hollywood and the Birth of the Modern Man | work=[[Thomas Dunne Books]] | year=2002 | isbn=0-312-28311-3 | publisher=Thomas Dunne Books/St. Martin's Press | location=New York, N.Y.}} but from the 1930s until 1968 the film industry in the US followed the [[Production Code]]. The code spelled out what was [[public morality|morally acceptable]] for a public audience; references to sexual "perversions" such as homosexuality were forbidden.{{cite web |url=http://www.artsreformation.com/a001/hays-code.html |title=The Motion Picture Production Code of 1930 (Hays Code) |publisher=Artsreformation.com |accessdate=2008-11-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222092920/http://artsreformation.com/a001/hays-code.html |archive-date=February 22, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://productioncode.dhwritings.com/container.php |title=The Production Code of the Motion Picture Industry (1930–1967) |accessdate=2008-11-25}} Virtually all motion pictures produced in the United States adhered to the code,Doherty, Thomas [http://my.brandeis.edu/news/item?news_item_id=105052&show_release_date=1 "The Code Before 'Da Vinci'"] ''[[Washington Post]]'' (May 20, 2006) and similar censorship was common in other countries, for example an early version of the first [[lesbian vampire]] film ''[[Dracula's Daughter]]'',{{cite book |title=Monsters and Mad Scientists: A Cultural History of the Horror Movie |last=Tudor |first=Andrew |page= 31 |year=1989 |publisher=Blackwell Publishing |isbn=0-631-16992-X }} a film described in ''[[The Celluloid Closet]]'' as presenting "homosexuality as a predatory weakness",{{cite book |title=The Celluloid Closet: Homosexuality in the Movies (revised edition) |last=Russo |first=Vito |authorlink= |page=48 |year=1987 |publisher=HarperCollins |location=New York |isbn=0-06-096132-5}} was rejected by the [[British Board of Film Censors]] in 1935, who said in part "...''Dracula's Daughter'' would require half a dozen ... languages to adequately express its beastliness.".{{cite book |title=The Hidden Cinema: British Film Censorship in Action, 1913–1975 |last=Robertson|first=James Crighton|authorlink= |author2=Ray Broadus Browne |pages=65–6|year=1993 |publisher=Routledge |location= |isbn=0-415-09034-2}} Horror author [[Anne Rice]] has named ''Dracula's Daughter'' as a direct inspiration for her own [[homoerotic]] vampire fiction,{{cite book |title=The Gothic World of Anne Rice |last=Hoppenstand |first=Gary |authorlink= |author2=Ray Broadus Browne |page=14|year=1996 |publisher=Popular Press | isbn=0-87972-708-X}} naming a bar in her novel ''[[Queen of the Damned]]'' "Dracula's Daughter" in honor of the film.{{cite news | last=Skal | first=David J. | title=Bloodsuckers and Cocksuckers: A Glossary of Vampirism and Sex | work=Bright Lights Film Journal No. 15 | page=11 }} Films produced under such censorship could only introduce homosexuality as a disguised undercurrent, and still flirted with controversy in doing so, such as in the cult horror film ''[[White Zombie (film)|White Zombie]]''.{{cite book |title=Monsters in the Closet: Homosexuality and the Horror Film |last=Benshoff |first=Harry M. |publisher=Manchester University Press }}{{cite book |title=White Zombie: Anatomy of a Horror Film |last=Don Rhodes |first=Gary |page=210 |year=2001 |publisher=McFarland |location=US |isbn=0-7864-0988-6 }} The less stringent rules of the post-Hayes film industry allowed sexuality to be more open, and cinema as a whole became more sexually explicit from the 1980s in particular, but aimed to purely to entertain rather than exploring underlying sexual dynamics. Much of the sex in speculative fiction film is merely intended to titillate; a review of fantasy films identified 10–15% as softcore pornography.Clute & Grant, p.xxx, "Pornography" but it remained rare to see gay characters in speculative fiction films. Horror films, that had sex as one of their major preoccupations, continued to be more leniently censored, due to the perception of being unserious and lightweight. Vampires in particular have been described as obvious erotic metaphors and as a result, numerous vampire films since the 1970s strongly imply or explicitly show lesbianism, following the inspiration of [[lesbian vampire]] story ''[[Carmilla]]''. The prototypical Hollywood vampire, [[Dracula]], was shown to be openly gay in the spoof film ''Does Dracula Suck?'' in 1969.{{cite book |title=Dark Romance: Sexuality in the Horror Film |last=Hogan |first=David J. |chapter=Lugosi, Lee, and the Vampires |pages=146–163|year=1997 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=0-7864-0474-4 }} Gay genre films remain rare,[http://www.afterelton.com/movies/2008/12/yearingaymovies?page=0%2C0 The Year in Gay Movies], ''[[AfterEllen.com and AfterElton.com|AfterElton.com]]'' and science fiction films' inclusion of gay characters continues to relegate them to supporting roles, such as the "stereotypical, limp-wristed, frantic homosexual" minor character played by [[Harvey Fierstein]] in the 1996 blockbuster ''[[Independence Day (1996 film)|Independence Day]]'',{{cite book |title=Alternate Americas: Science Fiction Film and American Culture |last=Booker |first=M. Keith |page=239 |year=2006 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |location=US |isbn=0-275-98395-1}} a film whose main theme has been described as being the anxiety surrounding male friendships and homosexual panic.{{cite book |title=From Alien to The Matrix: Reading Science Fiction Film |last=Kaveney |first=Roz |year=2005 |publisher=I.B. Tauris |isbn=1-85043-806-4}} It is also interesting to note that the film's director, [[Roland Emmerich]], is openly gay. Still there are some curious cases like Cthulhu (2007) a horror/thriller film based on the works of [[H. P. Lovecraft]], in which the main character is gay but it isn't the main thing, although it is important in the development of the character's psychology. The film is plagued with monsters and disturbing happenings. Also, in ''[[V for Vendetta (film)|V for Vendetta]]'' there are two secondary characters – one gay, one lesbian – shown as victims of the totalitarian [[dystopia]]. 2012 saw the light of the epic [[Wachowskis]] + [[Tom Tykwer]] blockbuster, ''[[Cloud Atlas (film)|Cloud Atlas]]'', featuring in one of the six stories a couple of gay characters. ===Television=== LGBT characters began appearing on television with increasing frequency only in the 1990s. The 1994 television science fiction show, [[Babylon 5]] introduced a bisexual character, [[Susan Ivanova]] whose relationship with a fellow female telepath was revealed in season 2 (1995). Advocate magazine called this relationship out as the closest that the Star Trek franchise or any "Star Trek clone," as he called the show, had come to a "gay creature—much less a gay human being."{{cite journal |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=TGQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA7&q=%22babylon%205%22%20same-sex |title=Gaywatch |journal=The Advocate |author=Vilanch, Bruce |date=January 21, 1997}} Babylon 5 continued to explore the state of same-sex relationships in the future with the introduction of a male-male marriage and subsequent honeymoon as cover for two of the main characters who were on a covert mission to a Mars colony in season 4.{{cite book |title=It's show time!: media, politics, and popular culture |author=Schultz, David Andrew |year=2000 |page=92 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=fgVpAAAAIAAJ&q=%22babylon+5%22+same-sex+mars |isbn=978-0-8204-4135-1}} The ''[[Xena: Warrior Princess]]'' fantasy television series introduced its main characters, [[Xena]] and [[Gabrielle (Xena)|Gabrielle]], as close companions; fan speculation about lesbian overtones led to them becoming lesbian icons, although the lesbian content remained at the [[subtext]] level.{{cite web|url=http://www.afterellen.com/TV/xena.html |title=Xena and Gabrielle: Lesbian Icons |work=Afterellen.com |author=Angie Beauchamp |accessdate=2008-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061019015939/http://www.afterellen.com/TV/xena.html |archivedate=October 19, 2006 |df=mdy }}{{cite web |author=Silver |date=October 14, 2007 |url=http://www.afterellen.com/TV/2007/10/topscifimoments?page=0%2C3 |title=The Top 11 Lesbian/Bi Moments in Sci Fi and Fantasy |work=Afterellen.com |accessdate=2008-11-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130116215338/http://www.afterellen.com/TV/2007/10/topscifimoments?page=0,3 |archivedate=January 16, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} The series has been cited as "trail-blazing" and breaking down barriers, allowing the production of subsequent programming such as ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'',{{cite web |url=http://www.cathyyoung.net/features/whatweowexena.html |title=What We Owe Xena |work=Cathyyoung.net |accessdate=2008-10-09}} which introduced a number of LGBT characters. The most famous is the major character, [[Willow Rosenberg|Willow]] and her partners [[Tara Maclay|Tara]] and [[Kennedy (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Kennedy]].{{cite web |url=http://www.afterellen.com/TV/buffy-end.html |title=How "Buffy" Changed the World of Lesbians on Television |publisher=Afterellen.com |author=Sarah Warn |accessdate=2008-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081017093306/http://www.afterellen.com/TV/buffy-end.html |archivedate=October 17, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} Although praised for their "healthy relationship" and being the first lesbian relationship between major characters on prime-time television, others criticised the use of witchcraft as a metaphor for lesbian sex. Tara's death directly after reconciliatory sex with Willow caused an outcry among the LGBT community, who saw it as a "homophobic cliché".{{cite book |title=The Warrior Women of Television: A Feminist Cultural Analysis of the New Female Body in Popular |last=Heinecken |first=Dawn |year=2003 |publisher=Peter Lang |page=104 |isbn=978-0-8204-6219-6}} [[Andrew Wells]], a recurring villain and eventual ally, was strongly implied to be gay, although closeted.{{cite web |url=http://www.afterelton.com/print/2008/1/tenbestscificharacters?page=0%2C0 |title=Ten Best Gay and Bisexual Science Fiction Characters |accessdate=2008-11-25 |year=2008 |publisher=AfterElton.com}} The series was influential on subsequent television speculative fiction, including ''Torchwood''.{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Rawson-Jones |title=Davies: 'Buffy', 'Angel' inspired 'Torchwood' |url= http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/article/ds38295.html?rss |work=[[Digital Spy]] |date=October 17, 2006 |accessdate=2006-10-19}}{{cite book |last=Walker |first=Stephen James |authorlink=Stephen James Walker |title=Inside the Hub: The Unofficial and Unauthorised Guide to Torchwood Series One |year=2007 |publisher=Telos Publishing |location=[[Tolworth]] |isbn=978-1-84583-013-7 |page=50}} The series won a number of LGBT themed awards,{{cite web|url=http://www.spectrumawards.org/2001.htm|title=Gaylactic Spectrum Awards – 2001 Information|publisher=}} and was regarded as groundbreaking in its portrayal of gay youth.{{cite web |url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/42996/buffy-the-vampire-slayer2/ |title=Popmatter: Buffy the Vampire Slavyer |accessdate=2008-11-25 |date=2001–2008 |work=PopMatters.com}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1582835/story.jhtml |title=Buffy The Vampire Slayer in Gay Romance For Next Comic Book Arc |accessdate=2008-11-25 |last=Vineyard |first=Jennifer |year=2008 |publisher=[[MTV Networks]]}} ''[[Torchwood]]'' is a British science fiction drama television programme, part of the long-running ''[[Doctor Who]]'' franchise, which began airing in 2006 on [[BBC Three]]. The series explores [[Themes in Torchwood|several themes]] in its narrative, in particular [[LGBT]] themes. Various characters are portrayed as sexually fluid; through those characters, the series examines homosexual and [[bisexuality|bisexual]] relationships. Although the nature of their sexual flexibility is not explicitly discussed, the characters offer varying perspectives on orientation,{{cite journal |last=Martin |first=Daniel |date=October 2006 |title=Jack of Hearts |journal=[[Gay Times]] |issue=337}} with ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' describing all of the characters on ''Torchwood'' as bisexual.{{cite web |url= http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/tv/article64139.ece |title=Dr Ooh gets four gay pals |accessdate=2006-10-06 |author=Sarah Nathan |date=September 2006 |work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] |quote=Gay ''Doctor Who'' star John Barrowman gets four bisexual assistants in raunchy BBC3 spin-off ''Torchwood''}} Series creator [[Russell T Davies]] has said that he hopes to defy audience expectations of [[monosexuality|monosexual]] characters: "Without making it political or dull, this is going to be a very bisexual programme. I want to knock down the barriers so we can't define which of the characters is gay. We need to start mixing things up, rather than thinking, 'This is a gay character and he'll only ever go off with men.'" Davies has also described [[Jack Harkness]] as [[omnisexual]]: "He'll shag anything with a hole. Jack doesn't categorise people: if he fancies you, he'll do it with you."{{cite news |first=Andrew |last=Williams |title=60 Second Interview: John Barrowman |url= http://www.metro.co.uk/fame/interviews/article.html?in_article_id=23649&in_page_id=11 |work=[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]] |date=November 2, 2006 |accessdate=November 3, 2006}} The inclusion of significant LGBT characters in modern speculative fiction television series has not been universal. For example, the ''[[Star Trek]]'' franchise's [[Sexuality in Star Trek|lack of same-sex relationships]] has long been a sore spot with LGBT fandom,{{cite web|url=http://www.webpan.com/dsinclair/trek.html |title=Gay, Lesbian & Bisexual Characters on Star Trek – a 12-year saga of deceit, lies, excuses and broken promises |author=D. Sinclair |date=October 19, 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090815081131/http://www.webpan.com/dsinclair/trek.html |archivedate=August 15, 2009 |df= }} some of whom have organised boycotts against the franchise to protest its failure to include LGBT characters. They also point out that [[Gene Roddenberry]] had made statements in later life favourable to acceptance of homosexuality and the portrayal of same-sex relationships in ''Star Trek'', but that the franchise's coverage has remained meagre. Within the ''Star Trek'' [[canon (fiction)|canon]], there have been no officially recognized LGBT characters in the television [[spin-off (media)|spin-offs]]. ''The International Review of Science Fiction'' ran a feature entitled "Prisoners of Dogma and Prejudice: Why There Are no G/L/B/T Characters in Star Trek: Deep Space 9"{{cite web |title=The Science Fiction Foundation: Foundation #86 |publisher=SF-foundation.org |year=2001 |url=http://www.sf-foundation.org/publications/foundation/backissues/fou86.html |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20050427211136/http://www.sf-foundation.org/publications/foundation/backissues/fou86.html |archivedate=April 27, 2005 |accessdate=2008-11-25}} However, [[gender identity]] has occasionally been treated as an "issue" within the new ''Star Trek'' series, to be dealt with as a theme in individual episodes, such as the 1995 ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' episode "[[Rejoined]]", which was the first episode of the show to feature a same-sex relationship and romantic same-sex kiss between women. Subsequently, the ''Star Trek'' franchise has portrayed a few same-sex kisses, but always in the context of either the evil "mirror universe" ("[[The Emperor's New Cloak]]") or body possession ("[[Warlord]]" and others), and often for comedic purposes between otherwise heterosexual characters. In a 2000 ''Fandom ''interview, ''Star Trek'' screenwriter [[Ronald D. Moore]] suggested that the reason why no gay characters existed in the television franchise was because someone wanted it that way, and no amount of support from fans, cast or crew was going to make any difference.[http://www.webpan.com/dsinclair/moore.html Frank Statements by Ronald D. Moore] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307063224/http://www.webpan.com/dsinclair/moore.html |date=March 7, 2009 }} In recent years, a few of the ''Star Trek'' novels and comics, which are officially licensed but not considered [[canon (fiction)|canon]], have featured serious direct same-sex relationships, including portraying a minor canon character as gay.{{cite web |url=http://www.gayleague.com/gay/characters/display.php?id=42 |title=Gay League: Characters |accessdate=2008-11-25 |year=2008 |publisher=Joe Palmer |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080405190644/http://www.gayleague.com/gay/characters/display.php?id=42 |archivedate=April 5, 2008}} In 2005 the television series ''[[Dante's Cove]]'' premiered on the [[here!]] cable station. The series included both gay and lesbian couples dealing with supernatural situations in the coastal town of the same name. The following year, [[Syfy]] premiered the series ''[[Eureka (U.S. TV series)|Eureka]]''. The series spotlighted a fictional town in Oregon that consisted almost entirely of geniuses. This included the town's café owner Vincent, who also happened to be gay. [[HBO]] brought then new series ''[[True Blood]]'' to the forefront of gay genre television, introducing a variety of omnisexual characters to the small screen in 2008 including: Lafayette Reynolds (played by [[Nelsan Ellis]]), Jesus Velasquez (played by [[Kevin Alejandro]]), Tara Thornton (played by [[Rutina Wesley]]), Pam Swynford De Beaufort (played by [[Kristin Bauer van Straten]]), Eddie Gauthier (played by [[Stephen Root]]), Russell Edgington (played by [[Denis O'Hare]]), and Rev. Steve Newlin (played by [[Michael McMillian]]). [[Stargate Universe]] in 2009 became the first space-based science fiction show to feature an openly gay character in its primary cast, which was "Camille Wray" played by [[Ming-Na]]. "Wray" was also the first gay character in the franchise and the first primary lesbian Asian-American character on primetime television.{{cite news |last=Warn |first=Sarah |title=Best. Lesbian. Week. Ever. (August 14, 2009) |publisher=AfterEllen.com |date=August 14, 2009 |url=http://www.afterellen.com/blwe/08-14-09 |accessdate=2012-04-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120717005322/http://www.afterellen.com/blwe/08-14-09 |archivedate=July 17, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |last=Gilchrist |first=Tracy E. |title=Ming-Na's History-Making Gay Universe On 'SGU': A SheWired Exclusive |work=shewired.com |publisher=Here Media Inc. |date=February 10, 2009 |url=http://www.shewired.com/box-office/ming-nas-history-making-gay-universe-sgu-shewired-exclusive |accessdate=2012-04-23}} Wray's storyline featured a committed long-term relationship with her Earth-bound partner Sharon (played by [[Reiko Aylesworth]]), the lifelike portrayal of which was very positively received by the lesbian community and press. Stargate Universe was cancelled after a two-season run.{{cite news |last=Hogan |first=Heather |title=Syfy cancels "Stargate Universe," we bid goodbye to our favorite space lesbian |publisher=AfterEllen.com |date=December 16, 2010 |url=http://www.afterellen.com/TV/2010/12/syfy-cancels-sgu-we-bid-goodbye-to-our-favorite-space-lesbian |accessdate=2012-04-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721201600/http://www.afterellen.com/TV/2010/12/syfy-cancels-sgu-we-bid-goodbye-to-our-favorite-space-lesbian |archivedate=July 21, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} In 2009 the series ''[[Warehouse 13]]'' premiered on the [[Syfy]] cable network. The series later introduced a character named Steve Jinks, played by actor [[Aaron Ashmore]], a gay government agent assigned to assist in the containment of bizarre artifacts. In 2010 a cable series prequel to ''[[Battlestar Galactica (2004 TV series)|Battlestar Galactica]]'' was introduced titled ''[[Caprica (TV series)|Caprica]]''. The series highlighted a world in which same-sex marriage was common. One of the central characters named Sam Adama, played by [[Sasha Roiz]], had a husband named Larry, played by Julius Chapple. In 2011 the cable station [[Syfy]] premiered the series ''[[Being Human (North American TV series)|Being Human]]'', an Americanized version of the previously released British series of the same name. A lesbian character named Emily Levison, played by actress [[Alison Louder]], was introduced as the sister to one of the main characters. That same year the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] cable series ''[[American Horror Story]]'' highlighted gay ghost couple Chad Warwick and Patrick, played by [[Zachary Quinto]] and [[Teddy Sears]]. The [[HBO]] cable station premiered ''[[Game of Thrones]]'', based on the book series of the same name. The series included gay couple Renly Baratheon and Loras Tyrell, played by actors [[Gethin Anthony]] and [[Finn Jones]]. [[MTV]] also premiered the cable series ''[[Teen Wolf (2011 TV series)|Teen Wolf]]'' that same year. One of the characters depicted is an out gay high school [[lacrosse]] player named Danny Mahealani, played by [[Keahu Kahuanui]]. ===Slash fiction=== {{Main|Slash fiction|Femslash}} The platonic close male relationships in television and film science fiction have been reinterpreted by fans as [[slash fiction]] – [[Kirk/Spock]] being the earliest example.David Seed Ed., ''A Companion to Science Fiction'', "Science Fiction/Criticism" p. 57, {{ISBN|1-4051-1218-2}} Slash cannot be commercially distributed due to copyright, and until the 1990s was either undistributed or published in [[zine]]s.Decarnin, Camilla (2006) "Slash Fiction" in Gaëtan Brulotte and John Phillips (eds.) ''Encyclopedia of Erotic Literature'' New York: Routledge, pp. 1233–1235. With the advent of the internet, the slash fiction community of fans and writers began to cluster at sites such as fanfiction.net,{{cite book |title=The Cambridge history of twentieth-century English literature |last= Laura |first= Marcus|authorlink= |author2=Peter Nicholls |year=2004 |publisher= Cambridge University Press|page= 798|isbn=978-0-521-82077-6}} and websites and fanzines dedicated to popular speculative fiction franchises such as ''[[X-files]]'' and ''Star Trek'' have become common. The use of characters from major SF franchises in "gay readings" has caused legal action: LucasFilm has sent cease and desist orders to prevent gay reinterpretations of ''[[Star Wars]]'' characters,{{cite book |title=Liquid Metal: The Science Fiction Film Reader |last=Sean |first=Redmond |authorlink= |page = 298 |year=2004 |publisher=Wallflower Press |location=US |isbn=1-903364-87-6}} and Anne Rice is notorious for attempts to stop production of slash fiction based on her ''[[Vampire Chronicles]]'' characters, although many of the characters are bisexual in [[Canon (fiction)|canon]].{{cite book |title=The Cambridge history of twentieth-century English literature |last= Laura |first= Marcus|authorlink= |author2=Peter Nicholls |year=2004 |publisher= Cambridge University Press|page= 800|isbn=978-0-521-82077-6}} Slash fiction has been described as important to the LGBT community and the formation of queer identities, as it represents a resistance to the expectation of compulsory heterosexuality,{{cite book |title=Science Fiction Curriculum, Cyborg Teachers, & Youth Culture(s) |last=Weaver |first=John A. |author2=Karen Anijar |author3=Toby Daspit |page=84 |year=2003 |publisher=P. Lang |isbn=0-8204-5044-8}} but has also been noted as being unrepresentative of the gay community, being more a medium to express feminist dissatisfactions with SF.{{cite book |title=Liquid Metal: The Science Fiction Film Reader |last=Sean |first=Redmond |page = 279 |year=2004 |publisher=Wallflower Press |location=US |isbn=1-903364-87-6}} According to polls, most of slash fandom is made up of heterosexual women with a college degree.{{cite journal | quotes = | last = Kustritz | first = Anne |date=September 2003 | title = Slashing the Romance Narrative | journal = The Journal of American Culture | volume = 26 | issue = 3 | pages = 371–384 | doi = 10.1111/1542-734X.00098 }} These demographics are older than the yaoi fans and they tend to be more easily disturbed about slash depicting underage sexuality,{{cite web |url= http://motspluriels.arts.uwa.edu.au/MP1901mcl.html |title= Local meanings in global space: a case study of women's 'Boy love' web sites in Japanese and English |last= McLelland |first= Mark |date=October 2001 }} but this is becoming less true due to the popularity of [[Harry Potter]]-inspired slash fiction.McLelland, Mark. [http://ro.uow.edu.au/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1152&context=artspapers The World of Yaoi: The Internet, Censorship and the Global “Boys' Love” Fandom] ''[[The Australian Feminist Law Journal]]'', 2005. [[Femslash]] is a subgenre of slash fiction which focuses on romantic and/or sexual relationships between female fictional characters,Lo, Malinda. (January 4, 2006) [http://www.afterellen.com/Print/2006/1/fanfiction.html Fan Fiction Comes Out of the Closet] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117044113/http://www.afterellen.com/Print/2006/1/fanfiction.html |date=January 17, 2008 }} [[AfterEllen.com and AfterElton.com|AfterEllen.com]]. Retrieved July 19, 2007. Typically, characters featured in femslash are heterosexual in the canon universe; however, similar fan fiction about lesbian characters are commonly labeled as femslash for convenience.Herzing, Melissa. (April 2005) [http://etd.vcu.edu/theses/submitted/etd-05092005-125907/unrestricted/herzingmj_thesis.pdf The Internet World of Fan Fiction]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[Virginia Commonwealth University]]. Retrieved August 12, 2007. There is less femslash than there is slash based on male couples – it has been suggested that heterosexual female slash authors generally do not write femslash,{{cite web|last=Thrupkaew |first=Noy |url=http://bitchmagazine.org/article/fan-tastic-voyage |title=Fan/tastic Voyage |publisher=Bitch Magazine |accessdate=2009-03-06}} and that it is rare to find a fandom with two sufficiently engaging female characters.{{cite web |last=Lo |first=Malinda |url=http://www.afterellen.com/Print/2006/1/fanfiction.html?page=0%2C1 |title=Fan Fiction Comes Out of the Closet |page=2 |publisher=AfterEllen.com |date=January 4, 2006 |accessdate=2009-03-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516121400/http://www.afterellen.com/Print/2006/1/fanfiction.html?page=0%2C1 |archivedate=May 16, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} Janeway/Seven is the main Star Trek femslash pairing, as only they have "an on-screen relationship fraught with deep emotional connection and conflict".http://j-l-r.org/asmic/fanfic/print/jlr-cyborgsex.pdf There is debate about whether fanfiction about canon lesbians such as Willow and Tara of ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' counts as "slash", their relationship storylines are more coy than heterosexual ones, which entices Willow/Tara femslash authors to fill in the gaps in the known relationship storyline.{{cite web |last=Lo |first=Malinda |url=http://www.afterellen.com/Print/2006/1/fanfiction.html?page=0%2C2 |title=Fan Fiction Comes Out of the Closet |publisher=AfterEllen.com |date=January 4, 2006 |accessdate=2009-03-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516121405/http://www.afterellen.com/Print/2006/1/fanfiction.html?page=0%2C2 |archivedate=May 16, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} It is "relatively recently" that male writers have begun writing femslash.{{cite web|url=http://slayageonline.com/Volumes/Slayage_Volume_4.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716091719/http://slayageonline.com/Volumes/Slayage_Volume_4.pdf |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |df= }} ==Reaction of the speculative fiction community== There has been a long history of tolerance of LGBT people in SF fandom. The presence of gay members was noted by attendees of early conventions, but generally not discussed — the idea that gay or lesbian members would seek recognition within the SF community was "unthinkable," and an accusation in the 1940s by a fanzine editor that the Los Angeles Science Fiction Association was "full of gay members" caused a scandal in fan circles.Bacon-Smith, p.136 Prominent SF fan [[Forrest Ackerman]] is regarded as one of the first members of fandom to openly support the gay and lesbian movements. He was known for writing early lesbian fiction and aided in the publication of ''The Ladder'', the journal of the recently formed lesbian group the [[Daughters of Bilitis]]. He claims the group named him an honorary lesbian for his support, and to have pseudonymously written the earliest work of "lesbian SF" in 1947 in ''Vice Versa'', the lesbian fanzine edited by [[Lisa Ben]]. As the number of works featuring LGBT characters increased, so did the visibility of LGBT fans. At least as early as the 1980 [[Worldcon]] ([[38th World Science Fiction Convention|Noreascon Two]]), there were gatherings of gay and gay-friendly members of the SF community, including [[Samuel R. Delany]], [[Marion Zimmer Bradley]] and [[Melissa Scott (writer)|Melissa Scott]].Bacon-Smith, p. 139 However, such meetings did not necessarily indicate whole-hearted acceptance within the fan community, and gay and lesbian fans were not regarded as a unified interest group. Informal gatherings at conferences and the attempted creation of a newsletter for LGBT fans drew little notice.Bacon-Smith, p. 140 Networking between gay fans continued, finally coalescing at the 1986 Worldcon into a plan of action. This led to the first [[Gaylaxicon]] [[science fiction convention]] being held in 1988 and subsequently to the creation of the [[Gaylactic Network]] and the [[Gaylactic Spectrum Awards]] by the [[science fiction fandom|science fiction community]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gaylacticnetwork.org/ |title=Welcome to the Gaylactic Network |work=GaylacticnNetwork.org |date=July 31, 2008 |accessdate=2008-11-25}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sfwa.org/news/00gaylac.htm |title=2000 Gaylactic Network Spectrum Awards |work=[[Science Fiction Writers of America]] |accessdate=2008-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220171028/http://www.sfwa.org/news/00gaylac.htm |archivedate=February 20, 2009 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.scifi.com/sfw/issue282/news.html |title=Science Fiction News of the Week |publisher=Scifi.com |accessdate=2008-10-09 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080514001314/http://www.scifi.com/sfw/issue282/news.html |archivedate = May 14, 2008}} Gay-themed discussions are now a staple at conventions such as [[WisCon]]; for example, WisCon 30 featured a panel discussing "Why Women Write About Gay Men", and the 38th World Science Fiction Convention in Boston had a discussion panel entitled "The Closed Open Mind – Homophobia in Science Fiction and Fantasy Stories". Other SF authors, such as [[Orson Scott Card]], have been criticised by the LGBT community for their works or opinions, which have been described as homophobic."Orson Scott Card Draws Gay Protest", 'Science Fiction Chronicles'' '''13'''(6), March 1992. Some lesbian science fiction is targeted specifically to a lesbian audience, rather than science fiction fans, and published by small feminist or [[lesbian fiction]] presses such as [[Bella Books]],{{cite web|url=http://www.afterellen.com/archive/ellen/Print/2006/7/publishing2.html |title=AfterEllen.com – A Survey of the Lesbian Fiction Publishing Industry |publisher=Afterellen.com |accessdate=2008-11-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120630025539/http%3A%2F%2Fwww.afterellen.com%2Farchive%2Fellen%2FPrint%2F2006%2F7%2Fpublishing2.html |archivedate=June 30, 2012 |df=mdy }}{{cite web |url=http://www.bellabooks.com/mm5/merchant.mvc?Screen=SUBS&Store_Code=bella |title=Bella Books & Distribution |publisher=Bellabooks.com |accessdate=2008-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222174234/http://www.bellabooks.com/mm5/merchant.mvc?Screen=SUBS&Store_Code=bella |archivedate=December 22, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} [[Bold Strokes Books]],{{cite web|url=http://www.boldstrokesbooks.com/|title=Bold Strokes Books|work=Bold Strokes Books}} Ylva Publishing,{{cite web|url=http://www.ylva-publishing.com/|title=Ylva Publishing: Home of Quality Fiction – Ylva Publishing|work=Ylva Publishing}} [[Regal Crest Enterprises]],{{cite web|url=http://www.regalcrest.biz/books.php|title=Regal Crest Titles|publisher=|access-date=September 2, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140716124541/http://www.regalcrest.biz/books.php|archive-date=July 16, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Bedazzled Ink,{{cite web|url=http://bink.bedazzledink.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517172155/http://bink.bedazzledink.com/ |archivedate=May 17, 2014 |df= }} Intaglio Publications,{{cite web|url=http://www.intagliopub.com/a-Sweeney.html|title=Intaglio Publications presents Kate Sweeney|publisher=}} and [[Spinsters Ink]].{{cite web|url=http://www.spinsters-ink.com/|title=Spinsters Ink|publisher=}} A notable author writing science fiction published by lesbian presses is [[Katherine V. Forrest]].{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/forrest_kv.html |title=Glbtq literature Forrest: Katherine V |publisher=Glbtq.com |accessdate=2008-11-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227012109/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/forrest_kv.html |archivedate=December 27, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} ==LGBT speculative fiction awards== A number of awards exist that recognise works at the intersection of LGBT and speculative fiction:{{cite web|url=http://www.locusmag.com/SFAwards/index.html |title=The Locus Index to Science Fiction Awards, compiled by Mark R. Kelly |publisher=Locusmag.com |accessdate=2008-11-25}} * The [[Gaylactic Spectrum Awards]] honour works in science fiction, fantasy and horror which include positive explorations of gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender characters, themes, or issues. The awards were instituted in 1999 and are given for best [[Gaylactic Spectrum Award winners and nominees for best novel|novel]], [[Gaylactic Spectrum Award winners and nominees for best short fiction|short fiction]] and [[Gaylactic Spectrum Award winners and nominees for best other work|other works]] of the previous year. Works produced before the awards' inception are eligible for entry into the [[Gaylactic Spectrum Award Hall of Fame inductees and nominees|Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|author=Rob Gates |url=http://www.spectrumawards.org/ |title=Gaylactic Spectrum Awards Foundation |publisher=Spectrumawards.org |accessdate=2008-11-25}} * The [[Lambda Literary Award]]s include [[Lambda Literary Awards winners and nominees for science fiction, fantasy and horror|awards for science fiction, fantasy and horror]]. The awards were first presented in 1989, with separate categories for speculative fiction for lesbians and gay men. In 1993 these categories were merged and the combined award has undergone several name changes since then. Although the awards are given based on the quality of the writing and the LGBT themes, the author's sexual orientation is also a factor.{{cite web|url=http://www.lambdaliterary.org/awards/guidelines.html |title= 2007 Lambda Literary Awards – Guidelines |work=Lambda Literary Foundation |accessdate=2008-11-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080528172700/http://www.lambdaliterary.org/awards/guidelines.html |archivedate = May 28, 2008}} * The [[James Tiptree, Jr. Award]] honours works of science fiction or fantasy that expand or explore one's understanding of gender.{{cite web|url=http://www.tiptree.org/ |title=James Tiptree, Jr. Literary Award Council |publisher=Tiptree.org |accessdate=2008-11-25}} Thus, it often goes to works which deal directly or tangentially with gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender issues.{{cite web |url=http://www.tachyonpublications.com/book/Tiptree2.html |title=The James Tiptree Award Anthology 2 |author=Karen Joy Fowler, Pat Murphy, Debbie Notkin and Jeffrey D. Smith (eds) |work=Tachyon Publications |accessdate=2008-11-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925134639/http://www.tachyonpublications.com/book/Tiptree2.html |archivedate=September 25, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} * [[Golden Crown Literary Society]] Awards (or "Goldies") are given to works containing lesbian themes or depictions of lesbian characters. Awards are given in numerous categories, including speculative fiction (or "SciFi/Fantasy/Horror") and [[paranormal romance]].{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204083315/http://goldencrown.org/site/index.php/top-awards|archivedate=February 4, 2009|url=http://www.goldencrown.org/site/index.php/top-awards |title=2008 Literary Award Winners |publisher=Goldencrown.org |accessdate=2015-10-27}}{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090208031017/http://goldencrown.org/site/index.php/awards-awards/2009-award-nominees|archivedate=February 8, 2009|url=http://www.goldencrown.org/site/index.php/awards-awards/2009-award-nominees |title=2009 Nominees |publisher=Goldencrown.org |accessdate=2015-10-27}} ==See also== {{Portal|Speculative fiction|LGBT}} {{colbegin}} * [[Sex and sexuality in speculative fiction]] * [[Gender in speculative fiction]] * [[LGBT literature]] * [[List of LGBT-themed speculative fiction]] * [[List of LGBT figures in mythology]] * [[Single-gender worlds]] * [http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpeculativeFictionLGBT Speculative Fiction LGBT] at TVTropes {{colend}} ==Footnotes== {{note label|Note1|a|a}} SF is used throughout as an abbreviation for speculative fiction, for convenience. Science fiction and slash fiction are written in full when referred to specifically.
{{note label|Note1|b|b}} Collected in ''[[In a Glass Darkly]]''.
{{note label|Note1|c|c}} Collected in ''[[A Saucer of Loneliness]]''.
{{note label|Note1|d|d}} Collected in ''[[Her Smoke Rose Up Forever]]''.
{{note label|Note1|e|e}} Collected in ''[[The Wind's Twelve Quarters]]''. ==References== ;Citations {{Reflist|30em}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |last= Bacon-Smith |first=Camille |authorlink= |year=2000 |title=Science Fiction Culture |chapter=Gay and Lesbian Presence in Science Fiction |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |isbn=0-8122-1530-3}} * [[John Clute|Clute, John]] & [[Peter Nicholls (writer)|Peter Nicholls]]. ''[[The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction]]''. London: Orbit, 1993 (2nd edition, 1999). {{ISBN|1-85723-897-4}}. * [[John Clute|Clute, John]] & [[John Grant (author)|John Grant]]. ''[[The Encyclopedia of Fantasy]]''. London: Orbit, 1997. {{ISBN|1-85723-897-4}}. * Dynes, Wayne R. with Warren Johansson, William A. Percy and Stephen Donaldson. ''Encyclopedia of Homosexuality''. Garland Publishing Inc, 1990. {{ISBN|978-0-8240-6544-7}}. pg. 752. * Garber, Eric & Lyn Paleo. ''Uranian Worlds: A Guide to Alternative Sexuality in Science Fiction, Fantasy, and Horror''. G K Hall, 1983. {{ISBN|978-0-8161-1832-8}}. * {{cite web|last=Marchesani |first=Joseph |title=Science fiction and fantasy literature |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/scifi_fantasy.html |work=GLBTQ.com – Encyclopedia of GLBTQ culture |accessdate=March 31, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150528020223/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/scifi_fantasy.html |archivedate=May 28, 2015 |df= }} * Pearson, Wendy Gay with Veronica Hollinger and Joan Gordon, (eds). {{about|the ethnic group that lives in Eritrea|the Manchu clan|Clan Nara|people from Nara|Nara (disambiguation)}} {{infobox ethnic group |group = Nara |population = 108,000 |popplace = [[Eritrea]] |langs = [[Nara language|Nara]] |rels = Predominantly [[Islam]];
Minority [[Christianity]] ([[Oriental Orthodoxy]]), [[Traditional African religion|Traditional faith]] |related = [[Kunama people|Kunama]], [[Nubians]], other [[Nilotic peoples]] }} The '''Nara''' are a [[Nilotic peoples|Nilotic]] ethnic group inhabiting [[Eritrea]]. The society is divided into four subtribes, who traditionally were animist but now follow Islam. They are mostly subsistence farmers. The Nara speak the [[Nara language]], which belongs to the [[Nilo-Saharan languages|Nilo-Saharan]] family. ==Overview== According to the Eritrean government, the Nara are descendants of the first [[Nilo-Saharan languages|Nilo-Saharan]] settlers in Eritrea, who had migrated from the [[Upper Nile (state)|Upper Nile]] area and intermarried with local [[Congo Pygmies|Pygmy]] populations.{{cite web|title=The people of Eritrea|url=http://www.shabait.com/about-eritrea/erina/17472-the-people-of-eritrea?format=pdf|publisher=Ministry of Information, Eritrea|accessdate=20 July 2016}} Today, the Nara number around 108,000 individuals. They constitute around 1.5% of the population of Eritrea. They are typically agrarian and have settled primarily along the border with [[Sudan]].{{cite book| title=Historical Dictionary of Eritrea| first=Tom |last=Killion |year=1998 | isbn=0-8108-3437-5}} The Nara population is divided into four subtribes: the Higir, Mogareb, Koyta and Santora. They traditionally adhered to [[Animism|animist]] beliefs.{{cite web|title=Eritrea: Nara People's History |url=http://www.madote.com/2010/04/eritrea-nara-people.html |accessdate=2010-02-09}} After the [[Egypt]]ian occupation in the 19th century, most Nara adopted [[Islam]].{{cite book|author=Mussie Tesfagiorgis G.|title=Eritrea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7pReFaFC3fQC&pg=PA177 |year=2010 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=978-1-59884-231-9 |page=177}} A minority also follow [[Christianity]]. The Nara ethnonym means "Sky Heaven". They also used to call themselves the ''Barya''.[[Luigi Luca Cavalli-Sforza|Cavalli-Sforza, L. Luca]]; Menozzi, Paolo; and Piazza Alberto ''The History and Geography of Human Genes'' Princeton, New Jersey: 1994 Princeton University Press "Ethiopians, Some of Their Neighbors, and North Africans" Page 173 ==Language== The Nara people speak the [[Nara language]]. It belongs to the [[Nilo-Saharan languages|Nilo-Saharan]] family, and is closely related to [[Kunama language|Kunama]].{{cite web|title=Nara|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/language/nrb|publisher=Ethnologue|accessdate=20 July 2016}} Through contact with neighboring [[Afroasiatic languages|Afroasiatic]]-speaking populations, many Nara are also bilingual in [[Tigre language|Tigre]] and/or [[Arabic language|Arabic]]. They traditionally had no writing system, with the few existing pieces of literature in Nara transcribed using either Tigre or Arabic. The language is also known as ''Nara-Bana'', meaning "Nara-Talk". ==Social organization== Social organisation of the Nara people is based on the clan and subclan, with people living in villages and hamlets. The lineage system is patrilineal, unlike that of the [[Kunama people]]. Land belongs to the clan and shared out among the families in the clan. ==Genetics== According to Trombetta et al. (2015), 60% of Nara are carriers of the [[Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)|E1b1b]] paternal haplogroup. Of these, around 13% bear the V32 subclade, to which belong 60% of the [[Tigre people|Tigre]] [[Semitic languages|Semitic]] speakers in Eritrea. This points to substantial gene flow from neighbouring [[Afroasiatic languages|Afro-Asiatic]]-speaking males into the Nara's ancestral [[Nilotic peoples|Nilotic]] community.{{cite journal |author1=Beniamino Trombetta |author2=Eugenia D’Atanasio |author3=Andrea Massaia |author4=Marco Ippoliti |author5=Alfredo Coppa |author6=Francesca Candilio |author7=Valentina Coia |author8=Gianluca Russo |author9=Jean-Michel Dugoujon |author10=Pedro Moral |author11=Nejat Akar |author12=Daniele Sellitto |author13=Guido Valesini |author14=Andrea Novelletto |author15=Rosaria Scozzari |author16=Fulvio Cruciani |title=Phylogeographic refinement and large scale genotyping of human Y chromosome haplogroup E provide new insights into the dispersal of early pastoralists in the African continent |journal=Genome Biology and Evolution |date=2015 |volume=7 |issue=7 |pages=1940–1950 |doi=10.1093/gbe/evv118 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Fulvio_Cruciani/publication/279186127_Phylogeographic_refinement_and_large_scale_genotyping_of_human_Y_chromosome_haplogroup_E_provide_new_insights_into_the_dispersal_of_early_pastoralists_in_the_African_continent/links/558d132a08ae40781c207a14.pdf |accessdate=1 September 2016 }}; [http://gbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/suppl/2015/06/23/evv118.DC1/Supplementary_Tables_1-7_Revised.xlsx Supplementary Table 7] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161226230059/http://gbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/suppl/2015/06/23/evv118.DC1/Supplementary_Tables_1-7_Revised.xlsx |date=2016-12-26 }} Cruciani et al. (2010) likewise observed that the remaining Nara individuals are primarily carriers of the Afro-Asiatic-associated haplogroup [[Haplogroup J (Y-DNA)|J]] (20%), as well as the [[Haplogroup A-L1085|A]] lineage (20%), which is instead common among Nilotes.{{cite journal|authors=Cruciani, Fulvio, et al.|title=Human Y chromosome haplogroup R-V88: a paternal genetic record of early mid Holocene trans-Saharan connections and the spread of Chadic languages|journal=European Journal of Human Genetics|date=2010|volume=18|pages=800–807|doi=10.1038/ejhg.2009.231|url=http://www.nature.com/ejhg/journal/v18/n7/full/ejhg2009231a.html|accessdate=1 September 2016|pmid=20051990|pmc=2987365}}; [http://www.nature.com/ejhg/journal/v18/n7/extref/ejhg2009231x3.xls Supplementary Table 3] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Ethnic groups in Eritrea}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Eritrea]] [[Category:Muslim communities in Africa]]

{{multiple issues| {{one source|date=February 2014}} {{original research|date=February 2014}} {{ref improve|date=October 2008}} }} A '''public computer''' (or '''public access computer''') is any of various computers available in public areas. Some places where public computers may be available are libraries, schools, or facilities run by government.
Public computers share similar hardware and software components to [[personal computer]]s, however, the role and function of a public access computer is entirely different. A public access computer is used by many different untrusted individuals throughout the course of the day. The computer must be locked down and secure against both intentional and unintentional abuse. Users typically don't have authority to install software or change settings. A personal computer, in contrast, is typically used by a single responsible user, who can customize the machine's behavior to their preferences.
Public access computers are often provided with tools such as a [[PC reservation system]] to regulate access.
The world's first public access computer center was the [[Marin Computer Center]] in [[California]], co-founded by David and Annie Fox in 1977.<ref>{{Citation | last = Fox | first = David | author-link = David Fox (LucasArts game designer) | title = About Us | date = 2007-08-18 | url = http://www.electriceggplant.com/about.shtml | accessdate = 2008-04-19}}</ref>
==Kiosks==
''See also: [[Interactive kiosk|Computer Kiosk]]''
A kiosk is a special type of public computer using software and hardware modifications to provide services only about the place the kiosk is in. For example, a movie ticket kiosk can be found at a [[movie theater]]. These kiosks are usually in a secure browser with zero access to the desktop. Many of these kiosks may run [[Linux]], however, [[Automated teller machine|ATMs]], a kiosk designed for depositing money, often run [[Windows XP]].
==Public computers in the United States== ===Library computers=== In the United States and Canada, almost all public libraries have computers available for the use of patrons, though some libraries will keep users timed to allow others to get turns and keep the library less busy. Users are often allowed to print documents that they have created using these computers, though sometimes for a small fee.
===School computers=== The U.S. government has given money to many school boards to purchase computers for educational applications. Schools may have multiple [[computer lab]]s, which contain these computers for students to use. There is usually [[Internet]] access on these machines, but some schools will put up a blocking service to limit the websites that students are able to access to only include educational resources, such as [[Google]]. In addition to controlling the content students are viewing, putting up these blocks can also help to keep the computers safe by preventing students from downloading [[malware]] and other threats. However, the effectiveness of such content filtering systems is questionable since it can easily be circumvented by using proxy websites, Virtual Private Networks and for some weak security systems merely knowing the IP address of the intended website is enough to go through.
School computers often have advanced operating system security to prevent tech-savvy students from inflicting damage (i.e. the [[Windows Registry|Windows Registry Editor]] and [[Task Manager]], etc.) are disabled on [[Microsoft Windows]] machines. Schools with very advanced tech services may also install a locked down [[BIOS]]/[[firmware]] or make kernel-level changes to the operating system, eradicating all chances of unauthorized activity.

"Пока там можно только поплавать"|website=66.ru|accessdate=4 June 2018}} | coordinates = {{coord|13|21|N|16|47|W|region:GM|display=inline}} }} The '''Romanov Empire''' ({{lang-ru|Романовская Империя}}{{cite web|url=http://russianempire.org/news/Zakon_O_ravnoznachnosti_naimenovanij_Suverennoe_gosudarstvo_Imperatorskij_Prestol_i_Romanovskaya_Imperiya.htm|title=Закон "О равнозначности наименований Суверенное государство Императорский Престол и Романовская Империя".|website=Russianempire.org}}{{cite web|url=https://rupolit.net/zakon-o-ravnoznachnosti-naimenovaniy-suverennoe-gosudarstvo-imperatorskiy-prestol-i-romanovskaya-imperiya|title=Принят Закон "О равнозначности наименований Суверенное государство Императорский Престол и Романовская Империя"|first=Александр|last=Устинов|website=Rupolit.net|accessdate=4 June 2018}}), also known as the '''Imperial Throne''' ({{lang-ru|Императорский Престол}}), formerly the '''Russian Empire''' (Российская Империя), is a state proposed by Russian businessman and politician [[Anton Bakov]] as a re-creation of the [[Russian monarchy]]. It would be led by [[House of Romanov|Romanov]] [[pretender]] [[Prince Karl Emich of Leiningen]] as Emperor Nicholas III, with Bakov serving as [[Archchancellor]]. By 2017, talks with heads of several countries were held to purchase a territory to establish a "non-micro" state: these included [[Montenegro]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], [[Albania]], [[The Gambia]], [[Antigua and Barbuda]] and [[Kiribati]]. In early 2017, it was reported that the Romanov Empire's founder [[Anton Bakov|Bakov]] was interested in acquiring three islands belonging to [[Kiribati]] in order to establish a "revived Romanov Empire".[http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/321693/russian-monarchist-eyes-kiribati-for-romanov-revival Russian monarchist eyes Kiribati for Romanov revival] — [[Radio New Zealand]], 4 January 2017. On 24 February 2017, the Kiribati government rejected Bakov's proposal for the islands.{{cite web|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/325266/kiribati-govt-rejects-russian's-proposal-over-islands|title=Kiribati govt rejects Russian's proposal over islands|date=24 February 2017|website=Radio.co.nz}} Bakov later claimed it wasn't the final decision and that it was related to an inner Kiribati political struggle.{{cite web|url=http://ekb.rbc.ru/ekb/28/02/2017/58b54df69a79470bf8881955|title=Президент Кирибати поддержал возрождение "империи Романовых" на островах|website=РБК|accessdate=4 June 2018}} On 1 December 2017, the Memorandum of Friendship and Cooperation between The Republic of The Gambia and Romanov Empire was signed in [[Banjul]] by the Secretary General of The Gambia, [[Dawda Fadera]], and the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Romanov Empire, Modou Lamin Saidykhan,{{cite web|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/345836/russian-empire-plans-shift-from-kiribati-to-the-gambia|title=Russian empire plans shift from Kiribati to the Gambia|date=9 December 2017|website=Radionz.co.nz|accessdate=4 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3488073|title=Антон Баков заявил о возрождении государственного статуса династии Романовых|date=6 December 2017|website=Kommersant.ru|accessdate=4 June 2018}} and on 6 December Bakov stated that the Romanov Empire was in talks with five other undisclosed countries. However, on 12 December the Gambia denied that such a memorandum was signed.https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-42324401 ==History== ===2011–2013=== Bakov declared the new Russian Empire to be the successor to the historical [[Russian Empire]] that ceased to exist in 1917. The Imperial Throne also claimed the right to maritime territories that were either claimed by the Russian Empire or discovered by the [[Imperial Russian Navy]] but never absorbed into the [[Soviet Union]].{{cite news|url=http://izvestia.ru/news/499236 |script-title=ru:Друг Немцова воссоздал Российскую империю на островке в 168 га |trans-title=Friend of Nemtsov Recreated the Russian Empire on 168-hectare Island|work=[[Izvestia]]|author1=Alexandra Bayazitova |author2=Olga Tropkina |author3=Yelena Shishkunova |date=1 September 2011|accessdate=30 January 2015|language=ru}} The 17 claimed territories include the entire continent of [[Antarctica]] and land under the jurisdiction of [[Japan]], the [[United Kingdom]], the [[United States]], and other nations.{{cite web|url=http://russianempire.org/content/about_podrobno.htm |title=About |website=Russianempire.org |accessdate=30 January 2015|language=ru}} Bakov declared himself prime minister and announced a constitution and state symbols.{{cite news |date=2 September 2011|url=http://newsbabr.com/?IDE=96948 |script-title=ru:Возрождена Российская империя |trans-title=Revived Russian Empire |work=Babr |accessdate=30 January 2015|language=ru }} The empire began to issue its own passports online for 1,000 rubles (US$31),{{cite news|url=http://rt.com/politics/monarchist-party-romanov-empire-579 |title=Russian Monarchists launch own party, Romanovs protest |work=[[RT (TV network)|RT]] |date=19 July 2012 |accessdate=30 January 2015}} and by 2014 it claimed it had granted about 4,000 passports to citizens.{{ru icon}} [[n:ru:Виртуальная «Российская империя» с одобрения Николая III обретает государственный суверенитет]] — [[Russian Wikinews]], 15 April 2014 Proponents of the new Russian Empire purport it to be the successor of the historical Russian Empire founded by [[Peter the Great]] in 1721. As such, the nation stakes its claim to unpopulated territory that belonged to the historical Russian Empire through "[[discovery doctrine|right of discovery]]", but which was not claimed by the Soviet Union after the 1917 [[Russian Revolution]]. It does not claim land that was part of the historical Russian Empire that is now part of Finland, Poland, or the former Soviet republics. In June 2012, Bakov registered the [[Monarchist Party]] with the [[Russian Ministry of Justice]], with a stated goal of restoring the monarchy to Russia in accordance with law. It is the only legalised monarchist party in Russia. In the fall of 2013, Bakov's daughter Anastasia Bakova (Анастасия Бакова) was the Monarchist Party's candidate in the mayoral elections in [[Yekaterinburg]]. In July 2013, Bakov claimed his nation granted citizenship to the [[statelessness|stateless]] [[Edward Snowden]], who at the time was in [[Moscow Sheremetyevo Airport]] seeking amnesty in Russia.{{cite news|url=http://regions.ru/news/2466444 |script-title=ru:Председатель Совета министров Российской Империи выписал Сноудену паспорт |trans-title=Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Russian Empire made Snowden a passport |agency=Regions|date=5 July 2013|accessdate=30 January 2015|language=ru}} === Accession of Prince Karl Emich === {{Details|Line of succession to the former Russian throne}} [[File:Karl Emich of Leiningen photo11.JPG|thumb|Anton Bakov and Karl Emich signing founding documents for the Imperial Throne]] On 31 March 2014, under the new name of the Imperial Throne, the micronation issued a manifesto announcing itself a [[sovereign nation]] and declaring that [[Prince Karl Emich of Leiningen]] (born 1952) had become its head with the title of ''Nicholas III, Emperor of All Russia'', as a successor to [[Nicholas II]]. The title claim emerged upon the Prince's conversion from [[Lutheranism]] to [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] on 1 June 2013. {{cite news|url= http://www.gosrf.ru/experts/533/ |script-title= ru:Империя – наше прошлое и будущее? |trans-title= Empire - Our Past and Future? |agency= Regions |date= 10 April 2014 |accessdate= 30 January 2015 |language= ru}} Karl Emich descends from the House of Romanov through his grandmother, [[Grand Duchess Maria Kirillovna of Russia|Grand Duchess Maria Kirillovna]] (1907-1951), eldest child of [[Kirill Vladimirovich, Grand Duke of Russia|Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich]], who in 1924 claimed the Russian crown from exile following the execution of his cousin [[Nicholas II]] in 1918. The Imperial Throne claimed that by his conversion, Prince Karl Emich had fulfilled the accession requirements of Articles 35 and 53 of the [[Russian Constitution of 1906|Fundamental Laws of the Russian Empire]] last established in 1906. Prince Karl Emich accepted the Orthodox name "Nikolai Kirillovich" (Николай Кириллович) to become ''Nicholas III'', and his (third) wife, ''née'' Countess Isabelle von und zu Egloffstein, who also converted, accepted the name "Yekaterina Fyodorovna" (Екатерина Фёдоровна). The manifesto and new constitution, signed by Nicholas III, proclaimed the goal of the Imperial Throne as consolidating people all over the world devoted to Christian monarchism. In this document, the Imperial Throne renounced all territorial claims of the Russian Empire (micronation). Romanov Empire aims to use modern technologies and plans to use [[cryptocurrencies]], declaring [[bitcoin]] the national currency and seeking investments via [[Initial coin offering]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20171228232314/https://www.znak.com/2017-12-26/anton_bakov_obyavil_bitkoin_nacionalnoy_valyutoy_sozdannoy_im_romanovskoy_imperii]{{cite web|url=https://rupolit.net/kandidat-v-prezidenty-anton-bakov-prisvoil-bitkoinu-status-natsionalnoy-valyuty|title=Кандидат в президенты Антон Баков присвоил биткоину статус национальной валюты|website=Rupolit.net|accessdate=4 June 2018}} ==Constitution and bylaws== According to its constitution, "the Imperial Throne is a sovereign state, a constitutional monarchy, the successor of the All-Russian Imperial Throne, and its claimed "predecessor", the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] and [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] thrones. Romanov Empire is the only state in the world in which the principle of [[sortition]] is used to form the upper House of Parliament of the State Duma."{{cite web|url=http://russianempire.org/content/konstituciya.htm |script-title=ru:КОНСТИТУЦИЯ СУВЕРЕННОГО ГОСУДАРСТВА ИМПЕРАТОРСКИЙ ПРЕСТОЛ |trans-title=Constitution of the Sovereign State of the Imperial Throne|website=Russianempire.org|language=ru|quote=1. Императорский Престол – Суверенное Государство, конституционная монархия, правопреемник Всероссийского Императорского Престола, и предшествовавших ему Римского и Византийского Престолов|accessdate=30 January 2015}} ===Council of ministers=== The nation's website proclaims a council of ministers (similar to the council of ministers set up by the actual Russian Empire), composed of the following:{{cite web|url=http://romanovempire.com/en/gov/ |script-title=Government|website=Russianempire.org|language=ru|accessdate=24 January 2018}} # Prince [[Anton Bakov]] — Chairman # [[Stanislav Belkovsky]] — Deputy Chairman # Tatiana Ignatova — Minister of Finance # Mikhail Strass — Minister of Bread and Land # Mikhail Verskajn — Minister of the Imperial Palace # Kirill Zhesterov — Minister of Justice # Modou Lamin Saidykhan — Minister of Foreign Affairs # Prince Ilya Bakov — Minister of Investment ==Geographic area== [[File:Taneti Mamau and Anton Bakov.jpg|thumb|Anton Bakov and [[Kiribati]] President [[Taneti Mamau]] during talks]] ===Proposed imperial palace and further talks=== After he was named Emperor, [[Prince Karl Emich of Leiningen|Nicholas III]] wrote a letter to [[Vladimir Putin]] requesting land in Yekaterinburg to establish a capital with its own imperial senate.{{cite web|url=http://www.monpartya.ru/news/politicheskaya_iniciativa_nikolaya_kirillovicha.htm|title=Политическая инициатива Николая Кирилловича, Принца Лейнингенского, по созданию в Екатеринбурге города-государства – Императорский Всероссийский Престол|website=Monpartya.ru}} The request was denied.{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.ru/content/201406/02/265.st.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141009104535/http://www.channel4.ru/content/201406/02/265.st.html |script-title=ru:Гость «Стенда» – Антон Баков, Председатель Монархической партии России|trans-title=Guest Anton Bakov, President of the Monarch Party of Russia|work=Channel4|date=2 June 2014|archivedate=9 October 2014 |accessdate=30 January 2015|language=ru}} In 2014, Bakov announced that he had purchased a {{convert|96|ha|km2}} plot of land in [[Nikšić]], [[Montenegro]] to build an imperial palace along with a Russian cultural center and Orthodox monastery.{{cite news|url=http://www.monpartya.ru/obzor/rossijskij_politik_stroit_imperatorskij_dvorec_v_chernogorii.htm |script-title=ru:Российский политик строит императорский дворец в Черногории |date=3 June 2014|accessdate=30 January 2015|language=ru}} Also in early 2015 Imperial Throne representatives claimed to be in talks with the authorities of the neighboring [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Albania]] on possible collaboration and future [[state recognition]]. Bakov held a meeting with Macedonian Prime Minister [[Nikola Gruevski]].{{cite web|url=http://imperor.net/en/latest-news/archchancellor-of-imperial-throne-anton-bakov-met-with-the-prime-minister-of-the-republic-of-macedonia/|title=Archchancellor of Imperial Throne Anton Bakov met with the Prime Minister of the Republic of Macedonia|website=Imperor.net|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160512122114/http://imperor.net/en/latest-news/archchancellor-of-imperial-throne-anton-bakov-met-with-the-prime-minister-of-the-republic-of-macedonia/|archivedate=12 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} Later there were talks with [[President of Gambia]] [[Yahya Jammeh]] at the [[Seventieth session of the United Nations General Assembly|70th UN General Assembly session]].{{cite web|url=http://imperor.net/en/aristocracy/gambian-press-welcomes-archchancellor-of-imperial-throne-a-a-bakov/|title=Gambian press welcomes Archchancellor of Imperial throne A.A.Bakov|date=19 October 2015|website=Imperor.net}} Also, talks were held with Macedonian and Montenegro Eastern Orthodox clergy — Bakov discussed creation of churches associated with Imperial Throne and proposed [[canonization]] of Russian ruler [[Ivan III of Russia|Ivan III]] and his wife [[Sophia Palaiologina]], who played significant roles in bringing Christian monarchy to Russia.{{cite web|url=http://www.gosrf.ru/news/19169/|title=Антон Баков: Бизнесмен не ходит строем|website=Gosrf.ru}} Talks with [[Gaston Browne]], Prime Minister of [[Antigua and Barbuda]], also took place.{{cite web|url=http://imperor.net/en/latest-news/delegation-of-russian-throne-on-official-visit-in-antigua-and-barbuda/|title=Delegation of Imperial Throne on official visit in Antigua and Barbuda|date=16 December 2015|website=Imperor.net}} === Kiribati developments === In May 2016 talks were held with the government of [[Kiribati]].{{cite web|url=http://kiribati.me/2016/05/11/977/|title=The official visit of the Archchancellor of the Imperial Throne Anton Bakov to the Republic of Kiribati|date=11 May 2016|website=Kiribati.me}} Later in 2016 talks were continued and in early 2017 it was announced by [[Radio New Zealand]] that the Kiribati government had agreed to assign three uninhabited islands in its [[Line Islands]]: [[Malden Island]] (for the Capital), [[Caroline Island]] and [[Starbuck Island]]. This may indicate future [[state recognition]], and transformation from [[micronation]] to [[sovereign nation]]. Later updates clarified that there are plans for an immediate injection of US$120 million into the Kiribati economy that will be followed by US$230 million of investments in construction of infrastructure at Malden island: hotels, fish factories and more.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/feb/07/russian-millionaire-plans-re-establish-romanov-empire-pacific-islands|title=Russian millionaire details plans to re-establish Romanov empire on remote Pacific island|first=Eleanor Ainge|last=Roy|date=6 February 2017|website=Theguardian.com}} According to Bakov, "a great number of Russian patriots who are not happy with Putin’s regime" are expected to arrive when the initial constructions are completed.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/30/russian-businessman-seeks-restore-tsarist-empire-overthrown/|title=Russian businessman seeks to restore Tsarist empire overthrown in 1917 on Pacific atoll|first=Jonathan|last=Pearlman|date=30 October 2017|website=Telegraph.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-38798535|title=Kiribati mulls 'Russian monarchy' plan|date=30 October 2017|website=Bbc.com}} From these times, the project has been branded under the new main name of the '''Romanov Empire'''.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/this-mans-quest-to-restore-the-russian-empire-isnt-going-well-1492351200|title=This Man’s Quest to Restore the Russian Empire Isn’t Going Well|first=James|last=Marson|date=16 April 2017|website=Wsj.com}} === Gambia developments === Bakov has been in similar talks with Gambia since 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.ural.aif.ru/politic/person/romanovskuyu_imperiyu_monarhista_bakova_priznali_oficialno|title=Романовскую империю монархиста Бакова признали официально|website=Ural.aif.ru|accessdate=4 June 2018}} In December 2017 he announced that the proposed declaration of partnership was finally signed and new Gambia authorities, headed by [[Adama Barrow]], had recognised the Romanov Empire. Bakov's [[land development]] companies now plan to create [[artificial island]]s in the vicinity of Gambia's capital, [[Banjul]], to establish territory for the Empire. The 6-year design works and talks took $6 million, and follow by talks on recognition with five other undisclosed countries. Furthermore, Bakov has proposed that Russian Olympic athletes, who were recently denied attendance to the [[2018 Winter Olympics]], compete under Romanov Empire flag.[https://web.archive.org/web/20171206170916/https://www.znak.com/2017-12-06/rossiyanam_predlozheno_vystupit_na_olimpiade_v_koree_pod_flagami_romanovskoy_imperii] == Symbols == The coat of arms of the "Russian Empire" consisted of a [[double-headed eagle]]. The flag of the empire is the [[Saltire|St. Andrew's Cross]], which was the [[Russian Navy Ensign]]. With the transformation into the Imperial Throne, the coat of arms was changed to a black Russian Imperial Eagle with the [[Chi Rho]] symbol in the [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]]. Bakov emphasized the Chi Rho symbolizes the formation of the Christian Monarchy in the [[Roman Empire]] by [[Constantine the Great]] who saw the symbol in the skies before the [[Battle of the Milvian Bridge]] in 312 AD. The eagle holds in its talons the [[sceptre]] and [[globus cruciger]], two of the most prominent symbols of Christian monarchy. == References == {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Micronations]] [[Category:States and territories established in 2011]] [[Category:Russian monarchy]]

{{Infobox serial killer | name=Ronald Dominique | birthname=Ronald Joseph Dominique | birth_date={{birth date and age|1964|1|9|mf=y}} | birth_place=[[Thibodaux, Louisiana]], U.S. | victims=23+ | country=United States | states=[[Louisiana]] | beginyear=1997 | endyear=2006 | apprehended=December 1, 2006 | penalty=[[Life Imprisonment]] }} '''Ronald Joseph Dominique''' (born January 9, 1964) is an American [[serial killer]] from the Bayou Blue area of [[Houma, Louisiana]]. {{cite news | url=http://www.houmatoday.com/article/20061207/HURBLOG/61207003/-1/news1001 | title=Video: Courier reporter, slain man's mother on CourtTV | work=[[The Courier (Houma, Louisiana)|The Courier]] | date=December 7, 2006 | accessdate=December 22, 2007 }} {{cite news | url=http://www.houmatoday.com/article/20061218/HURBLOG/61218002/-1/news1001 | title=Video: Courier reporter, slain man's mother on CourtTV | work=[[The Courier (Houma, Louisiana)|The Courier]] | date=December 18, 2006 | accessdate=December 22, 2007 }} Dominique was investigated in late 2006 following a police report by a man who refused to let Dominique tie him up. The final victim, Chris Sutterfield, had died about two months earlier. Following his arrest on December 1, 2006, Dominique confessed to the rape and murder of at least 23 men over a ten-year period beginning in 1997. He committed the crimes in [[Terrebonne Parish, Louisiana|Terrebonne]], [[Lafourche Parish|Lafourche]], [[Iberville Parish, Louisiana|Iberville]], [[St. Charles Parish, Louisiana|St. Charles]] and [[Jefferson Parish|Jefferson ]] parishes in suburban [[New Orleans]]. In his confession, Dominique, who is gay, said he frequented area [[gay bar]]s and targeted men he thought would be willing to have sex for money. He also lured straight men by setting up fake drug deals or showing men a picture of women and telling them that she was willing to pay for sex with a Black man. https://wondery.com/shows/real-crime-profile/ episode 52-55He murdered them to avoid being convicted and sentenced to prison for rape. He was charged with multiple cases of rape and [[first-degree murder]]. On September 23, 2008, Dominique was sentenced to eight life sentences after confessing to raping and killing his male victims over a 10-year period.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/09/24/louisiana-serial-killer-gets-8-life-terms-for-8-murders.html|title=Louisiana Serial Killer Gets 8 Life Terms for 8 Murders|date=September 24, 2008|publisher=[[Fox News]]|accessdate=4 July 2017}} Dominique pleaded guilty to first-degree murder in a deal to avoid the death penalty. He is incarcerated at the [[Louisiana State Penitentiary]] in Angola.{{cite web |author1=Chris Blondell |title=The Gentle, Pathetic Serial Killer |url=http://swordandscale.com/the-gentle-pathetic-serial-killer/ |website=Sword and Scale |accessdate=30 September 2018 |date=29 November 2017}}{{cite web |author1=Mike McPadden |title=Ronald Dominique: “The Bayou Serial Killer” Who Decimated Gay Louisiana - CrimeFeed |url=http://crimefeed.com/2017/09/32493/ |website=CrimeFeed |publisher=Discovery Communications, LLC. |accessdate=30 September 2018 |date=22 September 2017}} Dominique’s known victims are as follows: {| class="wikitable" |Name |Age |Date found |Location found |- |David Mitchell |19 |July 1997 |St. Charles Parish |- |Gary Pierre |20 |December 1997 |St. Charles Parish |- |Larry Ranson |38 |July 1998 |St. Charles Parish |- |Oliver LeBanks |27 |October 1998 |Metarie, Jefferson Parish |- |Joseph Brown |16 |October 1998 |Kenner, Jefferson Parish |- |Bruce Williams |18 |November 1998 |Jefferson Parish |- |Manuel Reed |21 |May 1999 |Kenner, Jefferson Parish |- |Angel Mejia |34 |June 1999 |Kenner, Jefferson Parish |- |Mitchell Johnson |34 |August 1999 |Metarie, Jefferson Parish |- |Michael Vincent |23 |January 2000 |Lafourche Parish |- |Kenneth Randolph |20 |October 2002 |Lafourche Parish |- |Anoka Jones |26 |October 2002 |St. Charles Parish |- |Datrell Woods |19 |May 2003 |Terrebonne Parish |- |Larry Matthews |46 |October 2004 |Terrebonne Parish |- |Michael Barnett |21 |October 2004 |Terrebonne Parish |- |Leon Lirette |22 |February 2005 |Terrebonne Parish |- |August Watkins |31 |April 2005 |Lafourche Parish |- |Kurt Cunningham |23 |April 2005 |Lafourche Parish |- |Alonzo Hogan |28 |July 2005 |St. Charles Parish |- |Wayne Smith |17 |August 2005 |Terrebonne Parish |- |Chris Deville |40 |September 2005 |Assumption Parish |- |Nicholas Pellegrin |21 |November 2005 |Lafourche Parish |- |Christopher Sutterfield |27 |October 2006 |Iberville Parish |} ==In Media== '''Documentary Film'''

[https://www.amazon.com/Serial-Killers-Rage-Horror-Anthology/dp/1542957788/ref=tmm_pap_title_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr= ''Serial Killers Rage and Horror: 8 Shocking True Crime Stories of Serial Killers and Killing Sprees''] - "Chapter 8.
